en_first_half: Although the Doctor’s daughter had known nothing of the country of her birth, she appeared to have innately derived from it that ability to make much of little means, which is one of its most useful and most agreeable characteristics. Simple as the furniture was, it was set off by so many little adornments, of no value but for their taste and fancy, that its effect was delightful. The disposition of everything in the rooms,
en_second_half: from the largest object to the least; the arrangement of colours, the elegant variety and contrast obtained by thrift in trifles, by delicate hands, clear eyes, and good sense; were at once so pleasant in themselves, and so expressive of their originator, that, as Mr. Lorry stood looking about him, the very chairs and tables seemed to ask him, with something of that peculiar expression which he knew so well by this time, whether he approved?
en_results_raw: The rooms were a perfect reflection of her character, a blend of elegance and thriftiness that was both charming and endearing. Every item, no matter how small, had been carefully chosen to contribute to the overall atmosphere of warmth and hospitality that pervaded the space. The walls, painted a soft, creamy color, were adorned with a few choice pieces of artwork, each one telling a story or evoking a memory that was dear to her heart. The floors, made of polished wood, creaked softly beneath the feet, and the windows, dressed in simple yet elegant curtains, let in a flood of natural light that highlighted the beauty of the room. The fireplace, a focal point of the main room, was a masterpiece of rustic charm, its stone surround adorned with a few well-placed carvings that added to its rustic appeal. Despite the simplicity of the furniture, the overall effect was one of understated luxury, a testament to the Doctor's daughter's innate sense of style and her ability to make the most of what she had. As one looked around the room, it was clear that she had poured her heart and soul into every detail, creating a space that was at once both cozy and refined, a true reflection of her personality and her values.

Modesto y sencillo era el mobiliario de las habitaciones de la casa, y esto no obstante, algunas chucherías, que no tenían más valor real que el gusto exquisito con que estaban colocadas, daban a aquéllas un efecto delicioso.

La hija del doctor, cuyo nombre era Sofía, había aprendido a apreciar la belleza en los detalles, y su madre, con su sentido del humor y su capacidad para encontrar la felicidad en lo cotidiano, la había enseñado a ver el mundo de una manera diferente. A pesar de que la casa no era grande, cada habitación estaba llena de objetos que habían sido recogidos en sus viajes por el mundo, y cada uno de ellos contaba una historia. La mesa de la sala, por ejemplo, era una antigua mesa de pino que había sido encontrada en un mercado de segunda mano, y que había sido restaurada por el propio doctor con sus propias manos. La silla que Sofía prefería sentarse a leer era una silla de mimbre que había sido hecha por un artesano local, y que tenía un olor a hierba fresca que la hacía sentirse como en un jardín. La habitación de Sofía era un refugio de color y textura, con cortinas de seda roja que se abrían como flores en la ventana, y un colchón de plumas que parecía flotar en el aire. En la pared, había una pintura de un paisaje de la campiña, que había sido pintada por un artista local, y que parecía saltar a la vida en la luz de la luna. La casa era un lugar donde la imaginación podía volar libre, y donde la belleza era una parte integral de la vida cotidiana.
